notesStmt.note: "Directions of the Lords and Commons assembled in Parliament" has a separate title page dated 1645 on A1r.
Caption title on p. 1: Die Martis, 19 Augusti. 1645. Directions for the election of elders.
Final 2 leaves contain resolutions of Parliament.
Copy filmed at UMI microfilm Early English Books 1641-1700 reel 2484 lacks two final leaves; variant.
Reproduction of originals in: Folger Shakespeare Library and Harvard University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: All the Å¿everall ORDINANCES DIRECTIONS AND VOTES OF THE LORDS and COMMONS AÅ¿Å¿embled in PARLIAMENT: For the Å¿peedy EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing of the Presbyteriall Government.
ORdered by the Lords AÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament, That theÅ¿e Ordinances, Directions, and Votes be forthwith printed and publiÅ¿hed.
Imprinted at London for John Wright at the Kings Head in the old Bayley. 1646.

DIRECTIONS OF THE LORDS and COMMONS AÅ¿Å¿embled in PARLIAMENT: After advice had with the AÅ¿Å¿embly of Divines, for the electing and chooÅ¿ing of RULING-ELDERS in all the Congregations, and in the ClaÅ¿Å¿icall AÅ¿Å¿emblies for the Cities of London and WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, and the Å¿everall Counties of the Kingdom: For the Å¿peedy Å¿etling of the Presbyteriall-Government.
ORdered by the Lords AÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament, That theÅ¿e Directions for electing of Elders in particular Congregations and ClaÅ¿Å¿icall AÅ¿Å¿emblies, be forthwith printed and publiÅ¿hed.
Imprinted at London for John Wright at the Kings Head in the old Bayley. 1645.

div.head: DIRECTIONS FOR THE Election of Elders.
div.p: 1 THat the Ruling Elders of a Parochiall and congregationall ElderÅ¿hip Å¿hall be choÅ¿en by the Å¿everall MiniÅ¿ters, and members of their Congregation reÅ¿pectively, being Å¿uch as have taken the Nationall Covenant, and are not perÅ¿ons under age, nor Å¿ervants that have no families.

2. That notice of Å¿uch election, and of the day when it Å¿hall be given by the MiniÅ¿ter in the publique aÅ¿Å¿emby the next Lords day but one before, and on that Å¿aid Lords day a Sermon be preached preparatory to that weighty buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e.
3 That no man be choÅ¿en for a Ruling-Elder but onely for one Congregation, and that in the place where his moÅ¿t Å¿etled dwelling and imployment doth lie.

4. That it Å¿hall be lawfull for the Congregation reÅ¿pectively, or any other perÅ¿ons to exhibite exceptions againÅ¿t any perÅ¿on elected as aforeÅ¿aid, touching the right of his election, or touching matter of ignorance, or Å¿candall, hereafter mentioned, within fourteene dayes next after the Å¿aid election to Å¿uch perÅ¿ons, MiniÅ¿ters, and others, as Å¿hall be appointed by Authority of Parliament, to receive the Å¿aid exceptions, which Å¿aid perÅ¿ons Å¿hall have power to receive, heare, and determine all complaints againÅ¿t any Elder of ignorance and Å¿candall, within the diÅ¿cription of ignorance and Å¿candall hereafter mentioned.

And Å¿hall have power to approve the perÅ¿on Å¿o elected, in caÅ¿e no juÅ¿t exception, as aforeÅ¿aid Å¿hall be proved againÅ¿t him. But if he Å¿hall upon juÅ¿t proofe be found ignorant or Å¿candalous, as aforeÅ¿aid, then to remove him. And if any of the Å¿aid Elders Å¿hall be adjudged to be removed, as aforeÅ¿aid, then another Å¿hall be choÅ¿en in his place as aforeÅ¿aid.

5. That Å¿uch Å¿hall be choÅ¿en for Ruling Elders as are men of good underÅ¿tanding in matters of Religion, Å¿ound in the faith, prudent, diÅ¿creet, grave, and of unblameable converÅ¿ation. And willing to undergoe the Å¿aid Office.

6. That all pariÅ¿hes and places whatÅ¿oever, (as well priviledged places, and exempt juriÅ¿dictions, as others) be brought under the government of Congregationall, ClaÅ¿sicall, Provinciall, and Nationall AÅ¿Å¿emblies. Provided, that the Chappels or places in the houÅ¿es of the Peers of this Realme Å¿hall continue free for the exerciÅ¿e of Divine duties to be performed according to the Directory.

7. That the Chappell of the Rolles, the two Serjants Innes, and the foure Innes of Court, Å¿hall be each of them a Congregationall PreÅ¿bytery within themÅ¿elves, and make a ClaÅ¿Å¿icall Presbytery in the whole.
8. That the Province of London Å¿hall be divided into twelve ClaÅ¿sicall ElderÅ¿hips according to the diÅ¿tributions hereafter following:

The firÅ¿t ClaÅ¿Å¿is to containe:
ALhallowes BreadÅ¿treet,
Andrewes Wardrope,

The twelfth ClaÅ¿Å¿is to containe:

9. That all the Å¿everall PariÅ¿hes and Places within the Cities of London and WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, and the parts adjacent, according as they are diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed into twelve Å¿everall ClaÅ¿Å¿is, Å¿hall
be the extent and bounds of the province of London.

div.head: Concerning the members of the ClaÅ¿Å¿icall and Congregationall AÅ¿Å¿emblies in the Å¿everall Counties.
div.p: THat in the Å¿everall Counties certaine perÅ¿ons, MiniÅ¿ters, and others, Å¿hall be appointed by authority of Parliament, who Å¿hall conÅ¿ider how their Å¿everall Counties reÅ¿pectively may be moÅ¿t conveniently divided into diÅ¿tinct claÅ¿Å¿icall Presbyteries, and what MiniÅ¿ters and others are fit to be of each ClaÅ¿Å¿is. And they Å¿hall accordingly make Å¿uch diviÅ¿ion, and nomination of perÅ¿ons for each claÅ¿Å¿icall Presbytery, which DiviÅ¿ions, and perÅ¿ons Å¿o named for every DiviÅ¿ion Å¿hall be certified up to the Parliament. That the Chanchellors, Vice-chancellors, and heads of the UniverÅ¿ities Å¿hall conÅ¿ider how the Colledges may be moÅ¿t conveniently put into claÅ¿Å¿icall Presbyteries, and doe certifie the Å¿ame up unto the Parliament.

And the Å¿aid Å¿everall ClaÅ¿Å¿is reÅ¿pectively being approved by Parliament within their Å¿everall Precincts Å¿hall have power to conÅ¿titute Congregationall ElderÅ¿hips where a competent number of perÅ¿ons Å¿o qualified for Elders, as aforeÅ¿aid,
Å¿hall be found. And where no perÅ¿ons Å¿hall be found Å¿it to be Elders, as aforeÅ¿aid, then that Congregation Å¿hall be immediately under the ClaÅ¿Å¿icall Presbytery, untill that congregation Å¿hall be enabled with members fit to be Elders, as aforeÅ¿aid.
The congregationall AÅ¿Å¿embly Å¿hall meet once every weeke, and oftner if occaÅ¿ion Å¿hall Å¿erve.
The claÅ¿Å¿icall AÅ¿Å¿embly Å¿hall meet once every moneth.

div.head: Concerning members of the Provinciall AÅ¿Å¿embly.
div.p: THe Provinciall AÅ¿Å¿embly Å¿hall be conÅ¿tituted of members Å¿ent from every ClaÅ¿Å¿is within the Province.

The number of the members Å¿ent from each ClaÅ¿Å¿is Å¿hall be Å¿o proportioned, as that the Provinciall AÅ¿Å¿embly may be more in number then any ClaÅ¿Å¿icall Presbytery within that Porvince. And to that end there Å¿hall be at leaÅ¿t two MiniÅ¿ters, and foure Ruling Elders out of every ClaÅ¿Å¿is. And that where there Å¿hall be need, the number may be increaÅ¿ed, as to the perÅ¿ons appointed for the bounding of the Provinciall AÅ¿Å¿embly Å¿hall Å¿eeme meet. Provided, that the
number doe not exceed nine of each, MiniÅ¿ters and Ruling-Elders, from any one ClaÅ¿Å¿is. And that there alwaies be two Ruling-Elders to one MiniÅ¿ter. That the Provinciall AÅ¿Å¿embly being conÅ¿tituted, Å¿hall meet twice every yeere, the firÅ¿t meeting Å¿hall be determined by the perÅ¿ons appointed for the bounding of the Provinciall and ClaÅ¿Å¿icall AÅ¿Å¿emblies.

div.head: Concerning the Nationall AÅ¿Å¿embly.
div.p: THat the Nationall aÅ¿Å¿embly Å¿hall be conÅ¿tituted of members Å¿ent from the Å¿everall Provinces aforeÅ¿aid, the number of the members from each Province to the Nationall AÅ¿Å¿embly Å¿hall be two MiniÅ¿ters, and foure Ruling-Elders. The Nationall AÅ¿Å¿embly is to meet when they Å¿hall be Å¿ummoned by Parliament, and to fit and continue as the Parliament Å¿hall order, and not otherwiÅ¿e.
